Author: Mylo#8306
Content:
Hey jl777 (or poly or shossain or decker or CG or alright or others)

Id like to write an article for my upcoming kmd blog about the bitcore integration that is the final article in relation to btc tech.

1)Bitcore enables `addressindex`?

2) Does bitcore enable other features?

3) Is the insight explorer the only explorer that is usable on kmd to take advantage of these features directly from blockchain? (As opposed to explorers that read a mongodb)

4) When was bitcore stuff added to kmd codebase?

Bitcore & explorers is one of my lesser known technologies inside kmd, plz excuse any dumb assumptions

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, it has addressindex, spentindex and timestampindex

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: without addressindex, CC would not be performant, in fact many would not be feasible at all

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: insight is the only one i know, but with the addressindex and spentindex rpc it shouldnt be hard to create a GUI to display it. not sure if anybody has

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it was added before CC, so a long time ago

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: @TonyL pesky bug is fixed. now it should maintain constant RAM usage (forever) with constant traffic levels and it shouldnt be crashing. however during the debugging it seemed that it is possible that not all packets for a tag would be in the list for the tag. careful submitting and counting of the DEX_list is needed to see if there is a problem. in the expected usage of just getting the latest packets, hopefully the counts will match.

Author: Mylo#8306
Content:
Thanks!

Ok that‚Äôs interesting about RPC possibilities. I was looking at a python explorer codebase because kmd already uses py cryptocondition test cases.  Perhaps this is a way of making a CC enabled explorer? (With python)

Or is nSPV also an explorer making possibility?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: nSPV would likely be too slow for an explorer, more designed for single client wallets

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: in any case, the nSPV talks to nodes with addressindex to get the addressindex data, so having a local node with -addressindex=1 is the way to go

Author: Mylo#8306
Content: Sweet. Interesting way to achieve result. That‚Äôs further great news about nspv tech.  Cheers

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i try not to follow the "expected" way to achieve results, rather to use deep understanding of the problem and the possible ways to solve it. then to choose the most "efficient". though defining what "efficient" means is not easy, other than "it feels the most efficient" and it takes into account the larger picture of complexity/security

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: also finding the most efficient is an iterative process, as you can see if you are following how -dexp2p is evolving

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: somehow without any mutex locks, it is processing and freeing memory in realtime, without crashes. likely some packets end up in limbo temporarily, but it is all within the design parameters of "as lossless as practical"

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i tried adding mutex locks, but it ended up deadlocking when i didnt expect it to and since it wasnt crashing without them, i pushed forward with the lossy approach

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: nothing prevents a lossless channel to be built on top of the existing messaging layer, so for now this seems the most efficient

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: That‚Äôs great! will make a test for list tonight and some stress testing

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: make sure to reduce the TXPOWBITS from 12 if you are doing stress test, it can be as low as 1 (or even 0 maybe) and that will save a lot of CPU cycles

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: to get a faster test of purging, you can reduce PURGETIME to 300 so it is a 5 min buffer, instead of one hour

Author: Mylo#8306
Content:
If mutex lock is not needed by this rotating buffer, brilliant. I did something similar with DECT cordless phone display (max characters) in hospitals for nurse call messages in the early 2000s. Obv not p2p complexity, but resource mgmt. it‚Äôs an awesome skill to have as a programmer.

Customizable purge time is useful for further applications.  Great!

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: all the main networking parameters are in #defines. with a bit of work i can make a bunch of command line switches so new networks can be spawned with different attributes, but that is low on priority list as you can just recompile

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: a threeway indexed rotating buffer of hashtables...

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: only system call is calloc/free

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i guess i can speed it up a bit more with a more efficient memory allocation, but it seems plenty fast as it is

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: all the code is in komodo_DEX.h, about 1300 lines so far and not much more left to get it feature complete.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: often i hear people complain about C saying it takes a lot of code to write stuff in, but not sure how much more compact any other language would be

Author: Mylo#8306
Content: Ok I‚Äôm not on the tools today, ipad, but can search mutex for info for dev update on this stuff in coming days.  Still working on the main content: bitcoin evolution (utxo, dpow, antara, nspv, bitcore*), smart chain projects* and where they innovate.  * still writing.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: dont make not having mutex any feature, it can certainly be that i need to add them to fix the orphaned packets bug that tony will find

Author: Mylo#8306
Content: Ok

Content: Just set CMD to what you need and KOMODO_BRANCH

Author: artemciy_dice#0049
Content:
BTW, at this stage I don't expect the AtomicDEX caretakers to use the coin tags. It is more likely that we'll pull the entire stream in, and sort it in an extensible fashion based on the component/system tags present *inside* the datablobs. For instance, if we have a gossip about peer X, this gossip might be relevant to order matching regardless of the coin (like when a KMD/BTC order matching takes into account the presence of a failed or successful DEX/LTC swap).
Maybe there will be uses for tags later, but having them is not our priority right now.
We might also want to share data with the komodod/dexp2p layer by adding datablobs that komodod would recognize and unpack.

Author: artemciy_dice#0049
Content: Thanks, @Sir Seven

Author: artemciy_dice#0049
Content: Given that caretaker is pulling the data in, and that the nodes join the "broadcast" from the current moment of time (without replay), there's likely no need to keep an entire hour of the data in RAM. I guess we'll be using a much smaller time window, in order not to store the data in memory twice. I'm curious if there are any pointers of what the minimal window could be?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: 120 seconds should work

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: maybe even 60 seconds

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: actually it could be set to 5 seconds

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but likely some bugs when it is so small

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if it is important, i can get it to work at 5 seconds, but that is probably too small as in some cases there could be lag. so i wouldnt go below 120 seconds

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i am testing at 300 seconds without any issues, dont see why 120 would have any problems

Author: artemciy_dice#0049
Content: 120 sounds fine! ty. and we'll need some of it as a buffer for comfortable caretaker restarts

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: there is MAXLAG #define that if you make it bigger, will extend the time a node will send pings to its peers with missing hashes, though on a disconnect/reconnect it might get confused and think a node will have the older messages

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but any sort of storage/caching/reliability layer can be added without much trouble to the current messaging layer

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: @TonyL can you test the missed packets again? i added a mutex in a few spots, hopefully it is a bit better. still seeing some issues on nodes at 100% CPU usage, but i think that is a different issue

Content: Sure, let me check

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: node generated a packet with a collision

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: should be harmless, just skips sending

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i use shorthashes, lowest 32bits and it is possible to get collisions

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: birthday paradox, with large number of shorthashes, odds go up of getting one, so when blasting a million it is a lot more common that would be expected

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: maybe thats why `n` is less in list

Author: jl777c#5810

Author: TonyL#3577
Content:
```#!/bin/bash

i="0"

while [ $i -lt 10000 ]
do
./komodo-cli -ac_name=DEXP2P DEX_broadcast $(( ( RANDOM % 1000000 )  + 1 )) 0 "tag10000" "tagsdfsf" "" "0.1" "100"
i=$[$i+1]
done```
